climbs.name: Simmer Down
climbs.fa: (TR) Troy Mayr, 1989, First lead: Dave LeWinter and Missick, 1992

content.description: A fun face with a big view but unfortunately a bit short to be more than a momentary diversion. Two stars out of five.
content.location:
This is the left of two routes on the south face of the summit block atop John Yablonski Rock. Hike east from Meteorite Crack until this south facing block comes into view.

Scramble up wherever is easiest to reach the base; the approach will likely take longer than climbing the route.

content.description:
This is the short finger crack on the right-side of the Hartman Slab.

Not much of a route, this starts from boulders around the right side of the slab. The crack starts out steep for a few moves, then goes through low angle patina. Descend a chimney/gully to the right.
This is a classic thin hands crack, with technical and aesthetic climbing.
content.protection: emphasize gear around one inch, since it's a thin hands crack
content.location: You can't miss this beautiful thin hands crack on a large boulder as you walk along the trail.  It faces west.

climbs.name: Heartbreak Ridge
climbs.fa: Ben Chapman, Sue Ann Murray & Warren Mellinger, 1/87

content.description: the crux is probably at the start(especially if you are short). Just below the second bolt, it gets a little thin.
content.location: about thirty feet left of Hartman you will find a boulder with two bolts on it. easily visible from the trail

content.description:
This is a beautiful though short crack on a a low angled slab easily visible from south Cap Rock. The climb begins at a short bulge to gain the crack. The crack ends at the top of the slab and it is possible to set an anchor directly above the crack or to move right onto a comfortable ledge above the slab.

The crack is clean and beautiful on the slab, making it worthwhile despite being very short. A good route for beginning leaders.
content.protection: Pro to 2" for the crack. A larger piece may be useful for anchors.

climbs.name: Guns in the Sky
climbs.fa: (TR) Troy Mayr, 1989, First lead: Dave LeWinter and Missick, 1992

content.description:
Another wee route with a big view but unfortunately it's a bit short even by Joshua Tree standards. One star out of five.

The name comes from an INXS song on their 1987 album Kick.
content.location:
This is the right of two routes on the south face of the summit block atop John Yablonski Rock. Hike east from Meteorite Crack until this south facing block comes into view.

Scramble up wherever is easiest to reach the base; the approach will likely take longer than climbing the route.

content.description:
A cool slabby climb right of Meteorite Crack.

Five bolts to a bolted anchor. There is a crack start (gear needed or solo) in the center, or an easy face start on the left (5.4 no pro), or up a gulley/chimney (tight fit) under a large chockstone to the right (4th class).
content.location: Just to the right of Meteorite Crack on John Yablonski Rock.

climbs.name: Barkhorn
climbs.fa: (TR) Bruce Christle & Denise Christle, May 1990, FL: Unknown

content.description: The low angled face 10 feet to the right of Hartman.
content.protection: No bolts. Lead Rawl or Hartman, or scramble up the gully to the right, to set a gear toprope anchor.
content.location: 10 feet to the right of Hartman, and to the left of Rawl.
